importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Prince Andrew stepped down from public life following a widely criticized BBC interview over his friendship with Jeffrey Epstein.
Prince Andrew and Virginia Giuffre reached an out-of-court settlement regarding the sexual abuse allegations.
A tribunal hearing revealed details of Prince Andrew's relationship with Yang Tengbo, including authorization for Yang to act on his behalf in business dealings with Chinese investors.
Virginia Giuffre died by suicide at age 41; a posthumous memoir describing her allegations is set for release.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2015 to 2019 marks the beginning and peak of public scrutiny over Prince Andrew’s ties to Jeffrey Epstein and allegations of sexual abuse, leading to widespread media attention and a public loss of credibility.

From 2022 to 2025, the situation evolved with a settlement, Giuffre’s death, and the release of her memoir, further fueling public discourse about accountability and truth in royal misconduct allegations.

keyTakeAways: Prince Andrew has formally relinquished the use of his royal titles, including Duke of York, following sustained public pressure and accusations related to Jeffrey Epstein and links to an alleged Chinese spy.
The decision comes after a long-standing legal and media controversy involving Virginia Giuffre’s allegations that Prince Andrew was involved in sex trafficking and sexual abuse, which he denies.

Public scrutiny intensified through a 2015 lawsuit by Giuffre and subsequent court proceedings, including a 2024 tribunal revealing ties with Yang Tengbo, a man linked to alleged espionage activities.

Andrew will no longer attend royal events such as Christmas celebrations, though he will retain his designation as 'Prince' due to being son of Queen Elizabeth II and will continue to live at Royal Lodge.
His former wife Sarah Ferguson will be known only as Sarah Ferguson, and his daughters Beatrice and Eugenie will retain their titles.
The move reflects a broader shift in public expectations for accountability within the royal family, especially in light of high-profile misconduct allegations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Prince Andrew has formally announced that he will give up the use of his royal titles, including Duke of York, following decades of public scrutiny and allegations linked to Jeffrey Epstein and ties with an alleged Chinese spy. The decision, made in consultation with King Charles and other members of the royal family, comes after a 2015 lawsuit by Virginia Giuffre, who alleged that Andrew participated in sex trafficking and sexual abuse with underage girls, including on Epstein’s private island and at his London home. Though Prince Andrew has repeatedly denied these claims, the accusations led to significant public pressure, resulting in the stripping of his military titles and charitable roles. A 2024 tribunal revealed that Yang Tengbo, a man with alleged espionage links, was authorized by Andrew to represent him in business dealings with Chinese investors. Following a settlement in 2022 and Giuffre's death in April 2025, the situation remains under public and media scrutiny. Prince Andrew will no longer attend royal events like Christmas celebrations, though he will retain his title as 'Prince' due to being the son of Queen Elizabeth II and will continue to live at Royal Lodge. His ex-wife Sarah Ferguson will now be known only as Sarah Ferguson, while his daughters Beatrice and Eugenie retain their full titles.
title: Prince Andrew gives up royal titles after string of scandals
